course_title: Introduction to Role of Science and Technology Education in Society

learning_outcomes.description: Develop, use and evaluate scientific explanations about everyday events including those that apply to technological practices. (APST 2.1, 2.2, 2.5)
Select and evaluate science and technology resources for use in the primary years of schooling classrooms. (APST 1.2, 1.5, 3.4)
Examine and compare the processes of science and technology and their use in schools (APST 4.1, 4.4)
Examine science and technology issues and plan for their use in the classroom setting. (APST 2.2, 2.6, 3.4, 5.2)
Evaluate social consequences of scientific and technological knowledge and practice. (APST 2.2, 2.5, 2.6)

assessments.task_description:
Starting in week 4, a written timed quiz will be administered in the lecture each fortnight. The quiz must be completed in person on the sheet provided. Responses must be handwritten unless there is an accessibility requirement. You are responsible for bringing your own pen or pencil. Students are not permitted to access electronic devices of any kind during the writing task, but may consult printed or handwritten notes. Any attempt to use Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

There are a total of 5 quizzes, each worth 6% of the overall course grade, with a focus on each of the content modules in the course. It will be held the week following the completion of the module. The quizzes may include short-answer questions and/or multiple-choice questions that refer to content from the readings, lectures, and/or tutorials. Multiple-choice questions will be marked as correct or incorrect. For each short-answer question, you will receive 50% for a partially correct answer, and zero per cent for responses that are incorrect or incomplete (whether unsubmitted because of non-attendance, submitted but blank, submitted but not responding to the question, illegible, etc.). You will also receive zero per cent if you have not followed an instruction to put away your device.

Feedback and answers will be given in the class immediately after the quiz. A score out of 6 for each quiz will be recorded on Gradebook on the Blackboard in a week. 

Criteria & Marking:

The overall grade for this task is calculated as a percentage by taking the points scored across all five quizzes and comparing it to the total points possible, e.g., 24 points allocated for correct answers out of 30 total points: 24/30 x 100 = 80%

This percentage is mapped to the UQ grading schema (below) to display a grade:

  • 84.5% and 100% = 7
  • 74.5% and less than 84.5% = 6
  • 64.5% and less than 74.5% = 5
  • 49.5% and less than 64.5% = 4
  • 46.5% and less than 49.5% = 3
  • 23.5% and less than 46.5% = 2
  • 0 and less than 23.5% = 1

assessments.task_description:
Rube Goldberg was famous for drawing cartoons that depicted very complicated machines designed to perform a simple task. The actual construction of a Rube Goldberg machine requires a good understanding of energy transfers, forces, and simple machines.

You will design and construct a Rube Goldberg machine that utilises at least three (3) different simple machines and at least two (2) energy transfers to successfully complete the end task.

Machine Rules

  1. The machine must complete a described task (as reliably as possible).
  2. Your machine must have a title.
  3. The machine must contain at least three simple machines and 2 energy transfers
  4. There must be a minimum of 5 steps (individual) or 8 steps (pair). There is no maximum number of steps.
  5. No live animals or hazardous materials may be used.
  6. The machine must not imply or contain anything inappropriate.
  7. Any loose or flying objects must remain within the set boundaries of the machine.

Task products

1.    The Machine – individually or in a pair

  • You will present your machine in a video.
  • The video should record your machine in action with no “cuts” and editing, and comment on the steps in the machine.
  • You should appear in your video with your machine.

2.      Individual task – each student will also complete a written assignment as a conclusion to the project. This will include:

  • The goal (what were you trying to accomplish?) A detailed drawing of your machine, labelling each step with A, B, C …
  • Provide a written explanation of each step
  • Include a description of the energy transfers
  • A completed Risk assessment form (a template has been provided)
  • Reflection documenting:
  • the process of developing and executing the task
  • issues and challenges associated with demonstrating a concept in physical form
  • links to the Australian Curriculum: Science.

assessments.task_description:
You are to apply your knowledge of science and technology theories, concepts and strategies to critically reflect on how your understanding of these evolves across the course. This progressive record of your observations, experiences, responses, collaborations, literature, and reflections will support your deepening understanding of the concepts that you will be expected to teach in the science and technologies learning areas.

Task Product: Reflective Journal:

  • Using the submission templates provided, you are required to submit reflections to questions at four junctures across the semester:
  • Week 1 (due 27 February): Initial reflections on teaching science and technologies content
  • Week 7 (due 17 April): Reflections on science pedagogies
  • Week 11 (due 15 May): Reflections on technologies pedagogy and course content knowledge
  • Week 15 (due 8 June): Reflections on placement observations of teaching science and/or technologies in the classroom
  • Your response to each question should be approximately 200 words, drawing upon science and technologies concepts, ideas, theories, research, strategies, and learning activities.

Extensions for the first three Reflective Journals above ONLY (Week 1, Week 7, Week 11) must be negotiated directly with the Course Coordinator.
